The effect of varying the metal ratio in a chromium molybdate catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane Harinarayana Bandaru Abdul S. Mahomed Sooboo Singh ⁎ Holger B. Friedrich School of Chemistry and Physics, Westville Campus, University of KwaZulu–Natal, Private Bag X 54001, Durban, 4000, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics Westville Campus University of KwaZulu–Natal Private Bag X 54001 Durban 4000 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Chromium molybdate catalysts with varying Cr/Mo ratios were synthesized by co-precipitation. The catalysts were characterized using XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPR, BET surface area measurements, ICP-OES and HR-TEM. X-ray diffraction and Raman studies revealed that the dominant phase in the catalysts was Cr2(MoO4)3. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy showed that excess Mo and Cr exist as MoO3 and Cr2O3 phases, respectively. The catalytic activation of n-octane was investigated from 350 to 550 °C, in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor with the GHSV fixed at 4000 h−1. Catalytic testing revealed that the conversion of n-octane and product selectivity varied with Cr/Mo ratio. At 6% isoconversion (350 °C), the stoichiometric catalyst, i.e. the catalyst with a Cr/Mo ratio of 0.67, produced octenes and carbon oxides as the major products with a selectivity of 51% and 49%, respectively. Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation n-Octane Chromium molybdate Chromium oxide Molybdenum oxide 1 Introduction The conversion of light alkanes to their corresponding olefins has attracted much interest in recent years. Currently, olefins are produced via the steam cracking of naphtha and by the dehydrogenation of paraffins. However, these processes have several disadvantages, such as high-energy requirements, coke formation, selectivity control and thermodynamic limitations [1,2]. Recently, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) has been investigated as the alternative technology to produce olefins, mainly due to the potential to overcome the major technical problems associated with dehydrogenation [3–6]. Recent studies have shown that the introduction of oxygen moderates carbon deposition on the surface of a catalyst [7,8]. The oxidation of alkanes is known to occur through parallel and sequential oxidation steps, where alkenes are primary ODH products. Carbon oxides (namely CO and CO2) can form by the secondary combustion of alkenes or through direct combustion of alkanes [9,10]. Mixed metal molybdates, such as bismuth molybdate and iron molybdate have been used in alkene oxidation and methanol oxidation respectively [11–18]. These molybdates are efficient as a redox catalyst, due to its various MO bonds [19]. It was suggested that these materials are bi-functional in nature [20]. One component, i.e. the MO bond, is responsible for the dissociation of molecular oxygen. The second component, i.e. the bridging oxygen (MOM), is responsible for chemisorption of the hydrocarbon. Subsequently, initiating the CH bond breaking and oxygen insertion [20–22]. In the case of bismuth molybdate as a catalyst for conversion of propylene to acrolein, it was proposed that propylene chemisorbed on the BiO site to form a surface allyl radical, further oxidized on a MoO site [23,24]. According to studies by Wachs et al. [20], who studied various metal molybdates for methanol oxidation, it was found that orthorhombic MoO3 has saturated Mo atoms on the surface, in contrast to iron molybdate, which has incompletely coordinated surface structures. As a result, MoO3 was less active towards methanol oxidation compared to iron molybdate [25]. It was also observed by Wachs et al. [17] that the surface metal concentration and Mo coordination influenced methanol conversion. Al-Zahrani et al. [26] have studied that the chromium oxides of different loadings ranging from 0.1 to 20 wt. % on gamma alumina were tested in propane ODH. At 450 °C, 10 wt. % loading exhibited propane conversion of 19%, where the gamma alumina support gave the best performance when compared to other supports such as MgO, TiO2 and SiO2. Same authors revealed that the nitrate precursor gave the best results compared to chromate precursors. Similarly, Jibril et al. [27] discovered that Cr-Mo oxide based catalyst supported on alumina showed that propane is oxidatively dehydrogenated to propene. However, CO appeared to be a secondary product produced from propene, whereas, CO2 exhibited a finite selectivity at low propane conversion, thus suggesting that CO2 mainly producing from propane. Tyagi et al. [28] reported that the counter metal ion (Cr3+) in the chromium molybdate lattice bonded with Mo6+ in the corners of tetrahedral coordinated MoO4 2− units through an oxygen atom, which is chemically isostructural to iron molybdate and bismuth molybdate [29–31]. Furthermore, they revealed that the Cr/Mo ratio has a strong influence on the reducibility, where the lower reducibility leads to lower selectivity to carbon oxides [4,26,32]. In the present contribution, we have aimed to design a catalyst with varied chromium and molybdenum metal ratios. This has been the subject of much debate with the recent studies of the area concluding that the active phase is stoichiometric metal molybdate [17,33]. This study aims to add to this debate by critically analysing the nature of the surface and subsequently, the catalytically active sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Catalysts with varying Cr/Mo ratio were prepared by the co-precipitation method. Suitable molar concentration solutions of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Sigma-Aldrich) and chromium nitrate (Cr(NO3)2·6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 100 cm3 double distilled water. Both the solutions were added dropwise to the round bottom flask, which is already contained 100 cm3 double distilled water under continuous stirring. The mixture was maintained at 80 °C and pH 5–5.5 by adding HNO3 (1 M solution) or NH4OH (1 M solution) as needed. After aging for 3 h, filtered the green precipitate, washed with water and dried at 110 °C overnight. Furthermore, the precursor was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h [16,34,35]. Bulk chromium and molybdenum oxides were prepared by the thermal decomposition of chromium oxide and molybdic acid, at 550 °C for 6 h. The Cr/Mo molar ratio of 0.4, 0.5, 0.67, 0.9 and 1.3 were denoted as CM04, CM05, CM067, CM09 and CM13, respectively to easily identify the ratio for the labelled catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by various physical and chemical techniques. The phase composition was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction, using a Bruker D8 Advance instrument with a copper radiation source of wavelength, 1.5406 nm and equipped with a Bruker VANTEC detector. The program used to control the instrument was Diffrac plus XRD Commander Software. The catalysts were scanned a 2-theta value from 10° to 70° at 0.5 degrees per minute and the long focus line with a voltage and amperage of 40 kV and 40 mA respectively. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed using a PerkinElmer Optical Emission Spectrometer Optima 5300 DV to determine the molar ratio of the two metals (i.e., chromium and molybdenum), where the sample (0.1 g) was digested using hot sulphuric acid. The calibration was done using 1000 ppm Cr and Mo standards (Fluka, RSA) with appropriate dilutions in the range from 0 to 100 ppm to determine the metal concentration in the catalysts. Brunauer- Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume studies were carried out in a Micromeritics TriStar II multi-point BET surface area analyzer. Samples (∼0.2 g) were degassed under a flow of nitrogen one hour at 90 °C, then one hour at 150 °C, subsequently degassed 12 h at 200 °C using a Micromeritics flow prep 060 sample degas system. The surface area was calculated by using the standard BET multipoint method, relative pressure ratio p/po values from 0.05 to 0.300 and adsorption branch of isotherm at p/po of 0.95 for pore volume calculations. The molecular structures of various metal oxide species in the chromium molybdate was analyzed using an Advantage 532 series Laser Raman spectrometer with Nuspec software. An argon ion laser line of 532 nm wavelength was used to excite the catalysts with a resolution of 1 cm−1 at room temperature. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were obtained using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Approximately, 0.05 g of the catalyst sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube using quartz wool to hold the catalyst particles inside. Prior to reduction, the catalysts were pretreated by heating to 400 °C under a stream of helium (30 mL/min) for 30 min and the temperature was decreased to 80 °C under the same stream of helium. The reduction experiments were carried out using 5 vol. % hydrogen in Argon as the reducing agent with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. At these conditions, the sample temperature was raised from the room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The degree of reducibility was calculated using the amount of hydrogen utilized during reduction and relating that to the reducible metal oxides present, assuming total reduction. An example of the calculation using catalyst CM067 has been added to the supplementary information. For high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), ethanol was added to the fresh catalyst and sonicated for 10 min. The samples were coated on 200 μm mesh copper grid covering with a thin layer of formvar and dried under a flexi desk lamp to form holes in grids. Images were captured using a JEOL JEM2100 HR TEM instrument made by Joel, Japan. Electron source used in the instrument is a lanthanum hexaboride filament (LaB6) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Particle size measurements were done using iTEM and ImageJ software. The catalysts surface structure and morphologies were observed using a Zeiss Ultra Plus field emission gun scanning electron microscope (FEG-SEM) with a Smart SEM Software. Samples were placed on aluminum stubs using a double side carbon tape and they coated at 20 μA sputter current with gold for 30 s, by using Q150R series high vacuum Quorum sputter coater which is fully automated. The Aztec software was used for EDX analysis coupled to Oxford instruments where they act as a detector and X-ray source. 2.3 Catalytic testing The gas phase reactions were carried out using a continuous flow fixed bed reactor functioning as down flow mode. A stainless-steel reactor tube with a 10 mm internal diameter and 300 mm in length was used to load the catalyst. All voids in the reactor tube filled with carborundum (40 grit, Polychem). 1 ml (∼0.8200 g) of the catalyst with a particle size between 1000–600 μm, placed between two cotton wool plugs, where the vicinity of the hotspot of the reactor tube. All the reactions were carried out at the temperature range of 350–550 °C, at 50 °C intervals. Carbon to oxygen molar ratio was adjusted using air, which is oxygen source and nitrogen as diluent inert gas and n-octane concentration in the gaseous mixture was 11% (v/v). The high precision isocratic pump (Lab Alliance Series-II) was used to deliver n-octane into the system and gases conveyed using air and nitrogen rotameters (AALBORG, USA). The reactor line temperature of 140 °C was obtained using glass fiber heating tape. The liquid products and the unreacted octane were collected in a catch pot cooled to about ∼2 °C and the volume of the gaseous components was measured by a wet gas flow meter (Ritter Drum-Type Gas Meter). The product stream (both liquid and gases) from the reactor were analyzed by Shimadzu-2020 gas chromatograph (GC) with Restek 1-Pona capillary column (50 m length and 0.25 μm diameter), equipped with flame ionization detector (FID). The gases products were injected into a Perkin Elmer Clarus 400 GC with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and Perkin Elmer Clarus 560 GC containing TCD for oxygen quantification, where they equipped with Supelco Corboxen capillary columns with different series 1010 and 5 A respectively, and with dimensions (30 m × 0.53 mm × 30 μm). A Perkin Elmer Clarus 500 GC–MS was used to identify unknown products from the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterisation 3.1.1 Powder XRD The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . X-ray diffraction patterns of polycrystalline chromium molybdates are with major d-spacing values of 4.32, 4.10, 3.83, 3.50, 3.43, 3.22 and 2.94 Å for 2θ angles between 10° and 70° correlating with JCPDS file no. 078-1654 [27,30]. The diffraction patterns for the CM04 to CM13 catalysts are not very similar to the patterns recorded for Cr2O3 and MoO3. Thus, the stoichiometry dictates presumably there should be extra chromium and molybdenum as oxide phases, but it was not observed in the X-ray diffractogram and so it is either amorphous or in a highly dispersed form on the surface of the molybdate [17]. The diffraction patterns were indexed with hkl values using the ICDD database with major peaks for the Cr2(MoO4)3 phase [30]. Several factors such as the amount of water, reaction time, pH, temperature and metal source play crucial roles in the formation of Cr2(MoO4)3. Hence, detailed studies indicating that the oriented attachment and layers self-assembly of sheets are responsible for the formation of this kind of structures [36]. 3.1.2 Surface studies The pore volume and BET surface areas of the catalysts were obtained based on adsorption isotherms of N2 condensation at 77 K, which also indicated that these samples are typically mesoporous materials. Thus, the BET surface area and total pore volume of CM067 are 12 m2/g and 0.05 cm3/g respectively, which is higher than that of pure Cr2O3 and MoO3 [20]. Results shown in Table 1 , show a slight increase in the surface area and pore volume between the chromium molybdate catalysts. 3.1.3 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy obtained for the catalytic materials shown in Fig. 2 , exhibited the characteristic bands of crystalline chromium molybdate [35,37]. The band at 962 cm−1 originated from the symmetric stretching of the MoO bonds in the tetrahedral MoO4 2− units [20,38]. The lowest observed frequency vibration at 461 cm−1 can be ascribed to bending modes and the bands at 850–800 cm−1 are related to antisymmetric vibrations of MoOM (MMo, Cr) bridging bands which are effectively involved in re-oxidation reactions [35,39,40]. Small peaks observed in the CM04 and CM05 at just below 800 cm−1, could be due to the MoO3 on the surface of bulk chromium molybdate. The highest intensity peaks of the chromium molybdate sample showed that there are few defect sites in the chromium molybdate microspheres [41]. According to Li et al. [42], the activity of the catalyst is influenced by the defect sites in the lattice, although the surface area of the catalyst also plays an important role during the formation of defect sites and catalytic activity. However, very little is known about the outermost layer of bulk mixed metal molybdates and essentially there is no molecular level structural information available [43]. 3.1.4 Temperature programmed reduction In ODH reactions, the redox properties of metal oxide catalysts play an important role in the activation of alkanes [3]. As shown in Fig. 3 , chromium molybdate exhibited the two reduction temperatures. The lower temperature (410 °C) reduction peak is due to the reduction of a small amount of monometallic oxides adsorbed on the surface of chromium molybdate and the second peak (565 °C) indicates the highest temperature reduction (T max ) of molybdate species. The higher temperature reduction peak is due to the reduction of chromium molybdate to molybdite and the spinel form of chromium molybdate (CrMoO4), which may be re-oxidised to the initial chromium molybdate phase (Cr2(MoO4)3). In the reduction of Cr2(MoO4)3, it is observed that molybdenum is reduced more easily from the Mo6+ to Mo4+ state than chromium in the compound [44]. In general, the reduction of the molybdates was more difficult compared to the individual metal oxides such as MoO3 and Cr2O3 and the lower temperature reduction peak diminished progressively with an increase in chromium loadings. 3.1.5 Electron microscopy Fig. 4 shows the SEM images at ∼30 K magnification, where we observed plate morphology for the chromium molybdate phase. SEM results indicated that chromium molybdate could provide a strong contact area and adequate active sites for the adsorption and desorption of products for the reaction. SEM images also provided information regarding homogeneity, with the chromium molybdate phase being, uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface. It is also observed that the images of the pure oxides are different to the images acquired for catalysts with the chromium molybdate phase. HR-TEM is a superlative technique to show the crystal morphology of bulk mixed metal molybdates [20]. Fig. 5 shows the HR-TEM images and selected area electron diffraction pattern (SADP) for the CM04 and CM067 catalysts after calcination at 550 °C, where the particles for all the catalysts ranged from 20 to 70 nm). The particle size of the CMs appeared to be slightly larger than that of chromium and molybdenum oxides. The images and SADPs of the other catalysts are shown in Fig S1, supplementary information. The selected area electron diffraction patterns of all the powders were observed to have molybdate structures with diffraction spots on the strong ring pattern with Miller indices correlating with the XRD patterns of the corresponding chromium molybdate. The diffraction spots increased with an increase in loading of both the metals, suggesting the enhanced crystallinity and increased crystallite size which revealed that there would be an oxide phase in the catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic results The activation of n-octane over the chromium molybdate catalysts, with varied chromium to molybdenum ratios, showed a variety of products. The products formed were octenes, aromatics, cracked products and carbon oxides. All the catalysts showed activities corresponding to their TPR profiles [45]. The TPR studies showed that the stoichiometric chromium molybdate had the greatest T max , which was the least reducible. At the same time it was observed that this catalyst gave the lowest selectivity towards CO x and highest selectivity towards octene isomers when compared at iso-conversion [46]. 3.2.1 Product selectivity with varying temperature The catalytic behavior of the various was shown to be different on a comparative basis, depending on the temperature [47]. At the lowest temperature studied, all the catalysts, except MoO3 and Cr2O3, gave a very similar conversion. However, this trend changed as the temperature increased. At the higher temperatures, 500 and 550 °C, a steady increase in the conversion was observed as the Cr content increased until the stoichiometric ratio was reached. Thereafter, the conversion decreased to a small extent, as the Cr content increased further. A somewhat similar behavior was observed for the oxygen conversion. This suggests that at the lower temperature, the active sites are similar for all the Cr/Mo catalysts, however, on increasing the temperature, the surface characteristics change such that some kinetic variance becomes inherent. Another argument could be related to the chromium oxide phase being dispersed on the surface of the chromium molybdate phase that then exerts its catalytic activity at the higher temperature [17]. Furthermore, the catalyst with the highest molybdenum content (i.e. CM04) showed low conversion when compared to the stoichiometric chromium molybdate at the same temperature. This could be due to the presence of molybdenum oxide distributed on the surface of the dominant chromium molybdate phase, in contrast to chromium oxide being present [20]. It was noted that the metal oxides had low activity especially at the lower temperatures likely due to the low surface area. The Raman spectroscopy showed the intense peak indicating the presence of bulk stable oxygen on the surface. This is explained by the presence of low bond length surface MoO, which is involved in the formation of alkenes from alkanes via ODH [20,48]. The octane adsorbed on the molybdate catalyst is activated by the surface oxygen species present in the tetrahedral units of MoO4 2−, which abstracts a hydrogen atom in the first step from the hydrocarbon molecule to form a transition alkyl radical and subsequently forms an OH group on the metal [7,48]. Fig. 6 and Table S1 in the supplementary section gives the results in terms of conversion and selectivity for the oxidative hydrogenation (ODH) of n-octane at various temperatures for all the catalysts. The selectivity behaviour of the catalysts also depended strongly on the Cr/Mo ratio. At low temperature (350 °C), the MoO3 catalyst gave the highest selectivity to octenes which decreased significantly as the Cr content increased up to a ratio of 0.5. The selectivity then increased for the stoichiometric ratio catalyst but decreased again as the Cr content further increased. This behaviour somewhat mirrors the reduction onset temperatures as shown by the TPR profiles in Fig. 3. The higher onset temperature of the stoichiometric catalyst suggests more difficulty in the reduction of the catalyst. In the context of the reaction being studied, this appears positive since there is a tendency for the catalyst to want to remain in the oxidized state. The consequence of this is perhaps a lower population of electrophilic oxygen species, which forms during the activation of molecular oxygen on the surface of the catalyst which tends to drive CO x formation. An estimation of the oxygen conversion indicate that the systems are operating under aerobic conditions, suggesting that this reaction is predominantly oxidative, but it is believed that the non-oxidative dehydrogenation over CM catalysts is likely to start in parallel when oxygen is unavailable at a given active site [49]. At high temperatures, the catalysts with a high chromium content exhibited the highest octene isomers selectivity even though the conversions were high. The stoichiometric (CM067) catalyst showed a marked decrease in selectivity at higher temperature with the maximum conversion reaching 10% at 550 °C. This data clearly showed that it is important to have a Cr/Mo ratio higher than that of pure chromium molybdate at temperatures above 450 °C to optimize the selectivity towards octenes, at high conversion. This is the primary role of excess Cr2O3 present in the reduced catalyst. The activity variation with the Cr/Mo ratio appears to be significant with respect to reaction conditions. Pure chromium and molybdenum oxides calcined at high temperatures possess lower activity. However, it is non-selective to value added products and produced cracked products at high temperature (500 °C and 550 °C). Cracked products start appearing at 400 °C and increased in selectivity beyond this temperature. The formed products follow two types of mechanisms, one is thermal cracking and the second is oxidative cracking. Thus, at low temperatures, cracking is more likely to occur through the oxidative mechanism, whereas, at high temperature, both thermal, as well as oxidative cracking takes place [2,49,50]. In general, the cracked products selectivity increased as the Cr content increased with Cr2O3 typically giving the highest selectivity for a given temperature. This suggests attenuation of the surface acidity by the increased presence of chromium oxide [2]. Further ODH of the formed octenes will lead to the formation of the C8 aromatics, and in the ODH of n-octane, re-adsorbed octenes are the precursors to C8 aromatics via octadienes and octatrienes [7,49]. The formation of aromatics started at 450 °C and increased with temperature over the CM catalysts. Moreover, the aromatics selectivity of CM067 was highest at 500 °C giving a selectivity of approximately 7%, however, the selectivity decreased to 4% when the temperature increased to 550 °C. The observed selectivity data suggests that the aromatization of n-octane over CM catalysts was poor at low temperature (350–450 °C), which suggests that the poorly reduced catalyst is unfavourable for the formation of C8 aromatic compounds such as styrene, ethyl benzene, and o-xylene. In general, the cyclization between the C1 to C6 leads to the formation of ethyl benzene and styrene, which is the favorable cyclization mode [5]. However, if the ring is closed through C2 to C7, o-xylene is the product that will form [8,51–53]. Carbon oxides (CO x ) selectivity followed the opposite trend to octenes selectivity. MoO3 showed CO x as the least dominant product at the temperature of 350 °C, however, an increase in the selectivity towards CO x was observed at high temperature (400–550 °C). A more detailed selectivity evaluation of CO2 and CO is given in Fig. 7 A and B, respectively. The n-octane oxidation studies over the chromium molybdate catalysts revealed that the selectivity to octene isomers also depended on the metal ratio (Fig. 8 ). Hence, the activities varied to some extent, but not in a systematic fashion. The CM catalysts with different metal loadings gave high selectivity towards trans-3-octene, which varied slightly with an increase in chromium concentration. The selectivity to trans-octenes was higher due to the relative thermal stability of trans-isomers compared to the cis-isomers [7]. The further breakdown of the octenes selectivity showed the dominance of the 2-octene isomers, and consequently, there was a lower selectivity observed for 1-octene, especially at low temperatures, however, it increased with an increase in temperature. This could be due to the mode of adsorption of n-octane onto the catalyst surface, which varied at high temperature (>450 °C) as the catalyst was reduced. Furthermore, 4-octenes were found to be the least produced octene isomers in all cases, because the elimination of hydrogen from the C4 position is unfavourable in the activation of n-octane [54]. In addition, apart from considering these thermodynamic factors; steric effects and the number of active centers are also responsible for the selectivity of octene isomers [5]. 3.2.2 Product selectivity at iso-conversion Product selectivity at iso-conversion was monitored at 350 °C (6% conversion of n-octane), is shown in Fig. 9 A and B. Among all the catalysts, the stoichiometric CM catalyst showed the highest selectivity towards octene isomers, which could be related to its higher reduction temperature compared to other catalysts. On the other hand, CO x selectivity generally showed an opposite trend to that exhibited by the octenes, which suggest that octenes are CO x precursors [46], and therefore slow desorption from the catalyst surface, as in the case of high chromium and molybdenum concentration (CM04 and CM13) which resulted in low octene selectivity. The concept of synergy contact is probably responsible for the promotion of one phase by the addition of a second phase, whereby a contact potential is created at the junction of two phases that favorably modifies the electronic density of the higher catalytically active phase [20,33]. In this case, chromium and molybdenum oxides have shown different synergy contact behaviour with bulk chromium molybdate, wherein they influence the product formation in ODH reactions. 4 Conclusion The present study showed that the stoichiometric solid solution of chromium molybdate catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation method and were found to be a mixture of metal oxide and Cr2(MoO4)3 phases. The metal ratios were determined by ICP-OES, where the excess metal contents formed their own oxide phases. Raman spectroscopy showed the low intense peaks which indicated that there were oxide phases present in the bulk catalysts. Similarly, TPR profiles showed that as the metal ratio (Cr/Mo) increased, reduction occurred at a lower temperature. The fact that surface tends to be mainly composed of oxide phases at higher loadings, where the uptake of n-octane at the surface of these various catalysts at ambient temperature appears to be directly related to the BET surface area. Oxidative dehydrogenation experiments showed that the dominant phase, which is the chromium molybdate phase, gave high selectivity towards octene isomers and low selectivity towards aromatics due to the formation of active oxygen species during the re-oxidation process. All the catalysts with different metal ratios showed moderate to high selectivity towards carbon oxides. Whereas, molybdenum oxide appears to be less active and more selective due to saturated double bond oxygen species. On the other hand, on chromium oxide there is bridging oxygen species, which is active in reduced phase. coredata.dc:description: Chromium molybdate catalysts with varying Cr/Mo ratios were synthesized by co-precipitation. The catalysts were characterized using XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPR, BET surface area measurements, ICP-OES and HR-TEM. X-ray diffraction and Raman studies revealed that the dominant phase in the catalysts was Cr2(MoO4)3. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy showed that excess Mo and Cr exist as MoO3 and Cr2O3 phases, respectively. The catalytic activation of n-octane was investigated from 350 to 550 °C, in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor with the GHSV fixed at 4000 h−1. Catalytic testing revealed that the conversion of n-octane and product selectivity varied with Cr/Mo ratio. At 6% isoconversion (350 °C), the stoichiometric catalyst, i.e. the catalyst with a Cr/Mo ratio of 0.67, produced octenes and carbon oxides as the major products with a selectivity of 51% and 49%, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of varying the metal ratio in a chromium molybdate catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane
